title: WHO’S WINNING, AND LOSING, THE WHITE HOUSE APPRENTICE?
content:
Since President Donald Trump began his tenure as the leader of the free world a little more than two weeks ago , his top aides have been jockeying for a greater share of power and influence in what has amounted to the juiciest , and most high stakes , season yet of The Apprentice . Like all truly great reality casts , the members of Trump ’ s inner circle have been busy figuring out each others ’ weaknesses and harnessing their strengths , occasionally , it seems , with well-chiseled picks . And whereas reality-TV viewers traditionally expect to read gossip about their favorite characters in the pages of Us or In Touch , fearful members of the republic now expect similarly dishy stories in The Wall Street Journal , The New York Times , and The Washington Post , all of which published alarming ( and , at times , scarily amusing ) reports this weekend illuminating the latest pecking order inside the West Wing .
In particular , reports focused on the fraught relationship between chief strategist Stephen Bannon and chief of staff Reince Priebus , Trump ’ s envoy to his base and party , respectively . During Trump ’ s first fortnight in power , the two appeared to represent opposing alter-egos within Trump ’ s brain , which makes them indispensable . They won the chance to accompany the president this weekend to Mar-a-Lago , where he spent his third weekend in office . Even though the stakes are far different , it was hard to disabuse oneself of the notion that Trump was planning some version of a West Wing rose ceremony . Even though politics , unlike reality TV , is not a zero sum game ( at least for now ) , shrewd viewers may wonder the inevitable : who , Priebus or Bannon , is likely to win the rose .
Priebus , according to a report from The Washington Post , has taken a greater share of control back from Bannon , who , straight out of the gate , took the reins to push through a series of executive orders in line with his nationalist vision . Bannon , for example , was credited with the “ extreme vetting ” order , which temporarily bans individuals from seven Muslim-majority countries and bars refugees from entering the U.S . The order , itself , has been temporarily halted by a court ruling , which has merely exacerbated the disastrous rollout . Key Cabinet secretaries and government agencies said they did not have the appropriate amount of time to vet the measure , which is perhaps why a number of judges across the country have halted the ban , questioning its legality .
A constitutional crisis is not exactly the image an incoming administration wants to portray in its first week . Ever since , Priebus has flexed his muscle in the West Wing . According to the Post , he has tried to get the White House into a rhythm , slowed the breakneck pace of executive orders , and has asserted that he needs more control over communication between agencies and the policy process in general . According to another report from The New York Times published on Sunday , Priebus has implemented a 10-point checklist that new initiatives must go through in order to avoid the kind of mess the so-called Muslim ban created for the administration to try to clean up .
This does not mean that Bannon ’ s role , a position so great that it earned him the title of “ The Great Manipulator ” on the cover of Time magazine , has necessarily diminished . Bannon noted to the Post that key advisers have simply figured out how to work together to get what they want . “ Some of us are a little more aggressive than others , and others have a more calming influence , and it ’ s what makes a perfect partnership , ” Bannon told the paper . “ There ’ s no daylight between us , and there ’ s really no daylight with the president . ”
content_original:
Since President Donald Trump began his tenure as the leader of the free world a little more than two weeks ago, his top aides have been jockeying for a greater share of power and influence in what has amounted to the juiciest, and most high stakes, season yet of The Apprentice. Like all truly great reality casts, the members of Trump’s inner circle have been busy figuring out each others’ weaknesses and harnessing their strengths, occasionally, it seems, with well-chiseled picks. And whereas reality-TV viewers traditionally expect to read gossip about their favorite characters in the pages of Us or In Touch, fearful members of the republic now expect similarly dishy stories in The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times, and The Washington Post, all of which published alarming (and, at times, scarily amusing) reports this weekend illuminating the latest pecking order inside the West Wing.

In particular, reports focused on the fraught relationship between chief strategist Stephen Bannon and chief of staff Reince Priebus, Trump’s envoy to his base and party, respectively. During Trump’s first fortnight in power, the two appeared to represent opposing alter-egos within Trump’s brain, which makes them indispensable. They won the chance to accompany the president this weekend to Mar-a-Lago, where he spent his third weekend in office. Even though the stakes are far different, it was hard to disabuse oneself of the notion that Trump was planning some version of a West Wing rose ceremony. Even though politics, unlike reality TV, is not a zero sum game (at least for now), shrewd viewers may wonder the inevitable: who, Priebus or Bannon, is likely to win the rose.

Priebus, according to a report from The Washington Post, has taken a greater share of control back from Bannon, who, straight out of the gate, took the reins to push through a series of executive orders in line with his nationalist vision. Bannon, for example, was credited with the “extreme vetting” order, which temporarily bans individuals from seven Muslim-majority countries and bars refugees from entering the U.S. The order, itself, has been temporarily halted by a court ruling, which has merely exacerbated the disastrous rollout. Key Cabinet secretaries and government agencies said they did not have the appropriate amount of time to vet the measure, which is perhaps why a number of judges across the country have halted the ban, questioning its legality.

A constitutional crisis is not exactly the image an incoming administration wants to portray in its first week. Ever since, Priebus has flexed his muscle in the West Wing. According to the Post, he has tried to get the White House into a rhythm, slowed the breakneck pace of executive orders, and has asserted that he needs more control over communication between agencies and the policy process in general. According to another report from The New York Times published on Sunday, Priebus has implemented a 10-point checklist that new initiatives must go through in order to avoid the kind of mess the so-called Muslim ban created for the administration to try to clean up.

This does not mean that Bannon’s role, a position so great that it earned him the title of “The Great Manipulator” on the cover of Time magazine, has necessarily diminished. Bannon noted to the Post that key advisers have simply figured out how to work together to get what they want. “Some of us are a little more aggressive than others, and others have a more calming influence, and it’s what makes a perfect partnership,” Bannon told the paper. “There’s no daylight between us, and there’s really no daylight with the president.”
